o1loWZB5ZYO5zyPwMUw1PA.text: The opulent (and obviously masculine) dining room feels designed to appeal to the international expenses crowd: without a view, you could easily be in Dubai, Chicago or Singapore instead of London. Deals are to be done here gentlemen... over steak, expensive wine and casual misogyny. That's a tad judgemental and almost certainly untrue but, being only a Rolex-throw from Mayfair, it is at least plausible.It has a vaguely Mid West American inspired opulence, though my descriptor is as lazy as the broad theming. Call it essence of robber baron... Thick, plush, arterial-red carpets? "make 'em plusher". Gilded, glowing fittings? "make 'em golder". Bulging list of rare American varietals in a leather-bound list? "make 'em rarer, and add a zero on..." The shock is that it's not American, but Danish. Despite channelling Smith & Wollensky or Chicago Cut, it comes from the land of stripped pine and Arne Jacobsen chairs. The only sign of this Scandinavian heritage on the menu came with a trio of Danish-origin 70 day dry-aged steaks. I'm not averse to the Stilton-like joys of aged steak, but a 45 day aged piece I had recently from the Ginger Pig bordered on overpowering at times, and anything getting close to 70 is going to be considerably and challengingly funky.Diving straight in, bypassing a relatively uninspiring starter list, we shared a surprisingly petit USDA Prime Porterhouse. It was wheeled up to be carved on a butcher's block. I was hoping for a lot from an expensive if troublesome cut. Advertised as fit for two or three, in truth it was probably only enough for one and a half or two with sides and starters. The problem with porterhouse is that you have two different cuts, sirloin and ribeye, separated by the thick T bone. Lesser chefs risk missing the balance and pushing the sirloin to a med/well, or leaving unforgiving ribeye fat un-rendered. As far as steaks go, this was a good 'un. Rich, buttery and with a decently deep flavour, it did everything a good steak should.Along with that hunk of prime meat, sides were measly for the price, and fine, generally just fine. Like supporting dancers in a meaty musical. Chilli fries came with a crunch and a crackle of heat, while a soothingly bland mac n cheese ticked our other carby box. You can't object to either, but at £4.50 a pop, I want to have the best darned carbs in the city. With a cocktail before, a digestif and a one of the cheaper wines (the leathery New World spell book unsurprisingly offered little below £40), we managed to splash £225 for two, certainly more than I'd expected.Tangentially, I remember being told by the International Man of Mystery, no stranger to the jet set, that this bland luxe internationalism is welcomed by many who spend half their lives in assorted high-end business hotels. "They want reassuringly expensive stuff they recognise, with the odd plain local speciality, because it's impossible to know how an authentic, highly spiced x, y or z is going to go down when you don't know which continent you're on and your body thinks that it's 4am..." With that in mind, MASH fits the bill perfectly. Just don't expect to see me back without the expense account.

Eax5pvdtEedzPlcU1g2quA.text: A bit on the pricy side, this venue has the most succulent steaks. If you want to impress your significant other with amazing decor and matching high-quality steak this is the place!

g7W145iSZorccjJjOaEdJw.text: This is a late review.  The last time I was here was somewhere in July of 2014. I really enjoyed the different types of steak  and meat cuts they have here at MASH.  It is by far one of the best steak restaurants I've ever had the pleasure of dining at. Super delicious steak!  Great service.  Took a group of friends (5 people) here. The DAMAGE came out to about $500 US dollars. A little pricey but well worth the money. The food was absolutely amazing!  I would highly recommend this restaurant to all you meat lovers!=)

riMzruHJE0qFBNFoBHxFZA.text: A great place for steak. The Art Deco basement resturant has a fantastic atmosphere and takes you back in time. Food is great and staff very well presented.

JSEbXZZ3q7ydWKH8Yolgrg.text: This new venue has great food, interesting drinks (bar and sommelier), stunning environment and attentive service.  Everything I want.  I just hope they can maintain it because although it's not cheap, it's hard to imagine they're getting the amount of business through the doors they need to cover their costs.  So, use it whilst it's hot.The playlist needs to work out whether to play the charleston or rock and they need to fill it up to bring that "hip n happening" atmosphere.  Otherwise, make mine a rare, I'm good to go.

T_d2EY1Kiu5J46dlI--wAw.text: I went here again for Valentine's day and I have to say the atmosphere in the restaurant is dead - even on a Friday night. It was the complete opposite of buzzy. The food was again incredible but the place is like a morgue. there are far too many tables and partitions all over the place so you can't see anyone around you. If you wanted to have a raunchy session in between courses you'd probably get away with it! The more vibrant Balthazaar, more intimate Hawksmoor, sexier Le Relais de Venise or the much cheaper Flat iron are way better and serve the same quality food. I won't be going back unless someone invites me and I don't have to pay.

PS0Go33gM3jrZp2vCafVNw.text: The only reason why I hang around Andrew M so much is because he is always on top of the game when it comes to getting the inside scoop on restaurant launches, soft opening resos, special deals.. on the flip side, he's also the reason why my pants no longer fit (I'm Canadian, yes, I said pants). To celebrate MASH's 1 year anniversary, they had a 50% discount on their main dishes.  This was great news for me - I love a good steak but the regular pricetag here is a bit much for me. Andrew and I decided to share the American rib-eye (600 grams), and the Danish longbone (500 grams), both priced at round £48 before discount.  I wasn't sure I wanted to go for the Danish cut since a few reviewers said not to bother, but Goetz said to try it, so I went with it.. and I'm so glad we did!  It was a favorite of the evening, aged 70-75 days, cooked rare, and there was definitely a stronger and meatier presence in the flavour.  I usually like having a bit of sauce on the side, but I didn't bother as I enjoyed the flavor of the longbone on its own.We had a few different starters and sides to share, including a steak tartare, shrimp linguine, sweet breads, foie gras (all at £9.50 each), chili fries, creamed spinach, mashed potatoes, green beans, and grilled chili peppers (at £4.50 each).  My personal favorite was the steak tartare - it was my first time trying it, and it was velvety smooth, and I'm not too sure what else they put in it but it was excellent.  I think it was something bordering lemongrass or ginger.  I would personally skip over the shrimp linguine (nothing special), and foie gras, as it didn't have that rich and smooth melt-in-your-mouth texture.  The sweet breads - everyone seemed to like this, but I'm not crazy about the texture of it.. so I wouldn't order it again.  Also just to note - chili chips isn't referring to American meat chili on top of fries (booooo!!), its just chili spice on the chips, though I didn't sense much heat.  Mashed potatoes were nice, creamy and buttery!  For dessert, I ordered a scoop of the pear sorbet and coconut ice cream.  I love both coconuts and pears, and they were really tasty, but coconut seemed to be a fan favorite at the table.  The rest of the evening went off without a hitch, the service was excellent, everyone ordered a cocktail or two, we even ordered a bottle of Magnum wine to share.  With a few more desserts, the final split came to about £70pp after discount.  Not bad considering all the food we got!  I'd definitely come back again (.. when I get a job..)

UmWFvFplo08oYNdbxXTYrg.text: Went there early evening. 3 adults and 2 young children. Was in the hood and wanted to try b1. Great setting2. Friendly service3. Ordered American steak and chips for for kids to share at GBP 25 . Steak tiny and lots of fat and sinew.  Fries soggy and smelled of fish. 4. Shared a medium rare Omaha NY bone in strip, which came rare unseasoned and was cut end to end at the table.  Was claimed to be 600g. I have had this in the US and couldn't finish it, though here they claim a lot of the fat renders and the bone is 75g. Very small and very fatty.  Final note on the steak : if serving table side, cut in the center and ask customer if acceptable. Ours was cut end to end and rendered useless to fire for a few more minutes. 5. Onion rings great.6. Tomato salad, weird shallots and herb dressing, but fine.7. Mac and cheese like from a tin, though served (poured) in a skillet.8. Fries were re-done and fine with excuse that a fuse went in frier and oil wasn't hot. A terrible excuse for any restaurant, let alone a  GBP 42 (USD 80) steak. How can't a chef see a grease pool of soggy fries, let alone not taste and let it through the pass?9. Was offered a coffee (passed) and also was topped up a glass of wine.10. Claimed to be a Danish version of an American steak house. Well, I and my 2 adult and 2 child guests have eaten at many steak houses across the US and all that Mash currently emulates is the "setting" of a high end steakhouse. 11. Completely style over substance.12. Real shame, as it could be great if they to had chef and kitchen that understood how to use their quality ingredients to make good basic food. .13. Shocked at why investors would let a shambolic and truly poor kitchen allow their investment and great ingredients to go down the drain. It ain't rocket science to make a good steak and fries! (and I and many others would pay top dollar if they did it right)14. Amazing wine list15. Staff consisted of host and well trained and meaning waiters. Never saw a Manager or Maitre D, and amazed that the person dealing with the complaints was the poor waiter. 16. Great setting.  Disappointing food.  Good service.  Badly managed.  Unjustified and expensive pricing.

NFA8KW0RPIcBitVVveDMXg.text: Friday night, no dinner reservation, 650pm, where can i go with clients?? MASH was seeming the only "decent" place I could find. We were greeted in style and from that moment on the service was impeccable. The staff are the best thing about this establishment. Situated in a basement with, what i am told, priceless interior fixtures and fittings from the start of the 1900's the place feels grand but to me this grandness made the place feel hollow and without soul. Its cavernous expanses were a little overbearing. We all stopped at the bar for a cocktail before being seated and there were no qualms about the tipples we were presented with. The bar had Soho-ista faux media types and their Panerai Luminor watches dripping off their wrists surrounding it so thankfully we were escorted to our tables before I had the chance to bump into Patrick Bateman. We had a lot of space and found the seating very comfortable and convivial to a decent evening then the wine got flowing and we ordered our starters: bland foie gras and mediocre carpaccio. We moved on to the steaks for mains and this is where I got MASH'ed off. No one enjoyed their steak. Don't get me wrong the steaks were cooked to order exactly but I was just very disappointed with the quality of the meat. For those prices, I expected to have my head blown off with by a bovine symphony. It felt more like a church hall than the Royal Albert Hall. We had dessert and coffees - the cheesecake and sorbet was very good and then then indigest... i mean the bill came. 450 smackers! Say whaaa. We all agreed by a country mile this was the most overly priced meal we'd ever attended in London. If we get Albert Hall we pay the Kings ransom, fair enough, but for this mediocrity, give me a break. Goodman's WIPES the floor with this place, easily. And Hawksmoor canters past it. I'd even choose Sophies steak house just for the value for money. Get real MASH and find better cuts.

1NIB6VUO7yF5r2bWJnAOKg.text: Love Mash, Have been there for drinks twice and can't wait to get back there for dinner.

BRBZ59wkMVrs3RYN6BVftg.text: Sit at the bar and enjoy a good bourbon with the bartenders. Only tried a starter. Seafood was not fresh.  Better bourbon selection at JW Steakhouse but better ambiance here.

VVVNNDDPMmFniIADKKLWmg.text: OMGBestSteakInLondon!!Exceptional service. Bread was amazing delicious. Steak perfectly cooked. Totally worth it. No jokes!

photos.caption: Photo of MASH - London, United Kingdom. Chocolate fondant dessert
Photo of MASH - London, United Kingdom
Photo of MASH - London, United Kingdom

SA0U4rzJwtjl8s3mzx8j1w.text: From the outside, MASH doesn't really stand out as anything special. In fact, I walked past it a couple of times, before I realised that that was the place (which probably says more about my focussed dependency on Google Maps when walking around, than the restaurant itself).But then you wander inside, and venture down the spiral staircases into a large room which wouldn't look out of place as a hip Art-Deco ballroom (minus Can Can girls and Flaming Skittles Jugglers). The main room has high ceilings and wide spaces, and though it seems loud, you can have a conversation without needing to raise your voice.We were seated at the bar, where we ordered a couple of 'El Prado' cocktails (which considering my name is Prad, it would have been criminal not to have!) and they were very delish - El Prado comes Prad recommended!When seated, we picked out our favoured steaks from the menu (Bone in Rib-Eye for me please, Medium-Rare) as well as haricot-vert and the much talked about Mashed Potatoes.Ah yes - the Mashed Potatoes. Our waiter talked a big game about the Mashed Potatoes, ensuring us that it was "The best in town". Now I don't want to boast about my connoisseur-experience of Mashed Potatoes across this fine city of London, but I've had my fair share and I was more than up for this epic-battle of the Beaten Spuds.So my verdict?Yeah, their Mashed Potatoes are very good. Like, very very good.But clearly nobody goes to a Steakhouse to sample the Mashed Potatoes. Unfortunately, the same deference  didn't seem to be given to the Steak. Although it was good, it wasn't *fantastic* - it was rather on the chewy side, and didn't have the rich taste I'd have expected in this price range. Basically, I've had *better*. If you're going to charge £60+, I expect to be carried out of the restaurant on a stretcher, in a meat coma.That said, it is several grades above those Gastropubs which are quietly cooking up Supermarket beef cuts, and doubling the price (Tut, tut).Overall, MASH is a great restaurant and a fine steakhouse if you're feeling particularly rich, or want a good place for a celebratory meal. And at the end of the meal, your bill will arrive in an envelope marked 'The Damage'.Quality.

photos.caption: Photo of MASH - London, United Kingdom. Porterhouse Steak!

lPqYv_hl1OMtS4tEpq5nWg.text: Did a team dinner here.  My UK team loved it and felt it was a great steak place.  Being from California and have a number of really nice steak places I would rank this as ok.   Steak was ok, I had a ribeye and most of others had a fillet.   We had the spicy fries with them and these had character. Ended with the sorbets which were flavorful.The ambiance is very nice, huge space with the filling of being in the open.

QCuhaLkLq6b5cB8xutjqOw.text: Must be in the top 5 steak places in London. We got the Porterhouse for two - amazing! And the sides are neat take on classics. Great ambience to boot.

VFm62oua6ppfy19CrwGQgA.text: Haven't even sat down for dinner... our bartender Steve (from.France) has made our experience beyond amazing already... makes magnificent cocktails,  and suggestions... as an added bonus, can give you recommendations for all of Europe... huge asset to a "American based" steakhouse and shows you a true appreciation of the Uk

kPsZ7tbgLUnlPvfR9eivwQ.text: Finally made it! Grand Danish restaurant with all the makings of an American steakhouse. Still, not quite American.It's hard to not be put off with the location. Piccadilly Circus? What self respecting Londoner wants to boast of having feasted on a fine steak in Piccadilly Circus? But maybe she can think of it as a Brewer Street institution rather than a Piccadilly hotspot? Of course, as she squirms her way into the not so labyrinthine sub terrestrial art deco space, she is greeted by this almost eerily formal, yet friendly atmosphere made up of happy, increasingly content diners.We ordered the foie gras, the smoked salmon and the steak tartare. Needless to say the steak tartare hit the spot. MASH has steak cuts from different countries, Uruguay, Denmark among others, and US and Australia. The steaks are exhibited in a fridge. there's a good choice of steak sauces to serve by the side.I had creamy mashed potatoes and bone marrow by the side of my Wagyu piece.Overall, while I will still give Hawksmoor half a star over MASH, I'm going to come back happily for more of that Wagyu and Uruguay steak.

sMaqCXIZTYVZqE3NihUhGg.text: A wonderful experience from the moment you walk in the door. The space is vast, the  tables are very comfortable and well-sized, but also provide a private feel. Great wine selection at reasonable prices. Recommendations include the dry aged steak and the Mash tartare. The dry age steak does not need a sauce, although they offer several nice ones. Service was wonderful (not overbearing, but never an empty glass). A class experience from start to finish at a reasonable price.

T5H2baJFhJU6Sctb5rTEaA.text: MASH is the kind of retro-styled classy space that I always dreamed of finding but never knew about. And it's buried underground right in the heart of Soho. I would never have expected that.I came here on Andrew M's expertly curated Classy Christmas (cocktail) Crawl, and so my culinary observations are confined solely to the '$5 dollar shake' consisting of Bourbon, cognac, ice cream, milk, popcorn and salted caramel. That shake was well-presented and tasty enough, though the paper straw proved a bit of a design flaw towards the end when its shake-logged structure made it difficult to finish off the last bitBut that's not what really impressed me here. Rather it was the space: the high ceilings, booths, low-lighting, and classic styling. With smartly-attired, helpful staff, this is a great place to impress a date, escape the hubbub street-side or briefly transport yourself to days gone past.I hope to return soon to try their steaks..

wgkSTYfIg9Z1shY-v-GSmQ.text: I come to MASH all the time for drinks/happy hour. I love the bar area and I think it's one of the best in London. They have very good, reasonably priced wines and the service is always great. I've had dinner here once and remember having the Uruguay fillet with bernaise sauce and a salad. I was very impressed. I'd like to visit the original Copenhagen restaurant too.

JQqHcO9ZU-_rGjxNVGIgyw.text: If there was a way on Yelp to give this place a 3.5 rather than a 4, that's what I'd do... but in this case I decided to round up.Atmosphere: 5/5Bar/Drinks: 5/5Food: 3/5Service: 4/5Value: 3/5In short: this is a cool place, but it's a bit hit and miss. The bar is absolutely fantastic, and stores one of the largest collections of bourbons (known brands and small batch) that I've ever seen in London. The restaurant... well, the steak is good. Get the American Rib Eye, forget the Danish aged meats, and don't bother with any of the fancy sides, and avoid the steak tartare. Dessert go for the profiteroles. Everything else is meh. Read below for more details.If I could split this review into 2, one for the bar, and one for the restaurant, that's what I'd do. The bar is a 5/5 experience. Troels, the bar tender who was serving me, mixed me an amazing Old Fashioned using FEW Spirits Rye whiskey, one of my favorite spirits currently. It was perfectly balanced, and delectable; just enough bitter, and enough Rye to melt my liver. Plus, he's a good guy. We had a nice chat about Paul Hletko's cheeky line of FEW spirits, including a nice 'side bar' discussion on what goes well with their Barrel Aged Gin, which is absolutely fantastic and wonderfully aromatic. Thanks to Master of Malt and Ginuine Spirits for bringing such fine, lesser known spirits into the UK. Disruption at work, ladies and gentlemen.I then proceeded to have another with Bernheim Original Kentucky Straight Wheat Whiskey. Packs a bunch, but my god, is that smooth. I will definitely be going back to have drinks at the bar, especially since it wasn't overly crowded at 7pm on a Friday night. Busy, but not packed. Now for the restaurant... was really looking forward to a hopeful alternative to The Hawksmoor's clear domination of London's American Steakhouse landscape... despite having rolled out many more restaurants through out the city, including one conveniently located on Air Street of Piccadilly, Hawksmoor is extremely hard to book last minute... a good problem to have, but frustrating to the say the least. Ok, ok, this is not a review about Hawksmoor, so let's get back to MASH.The starters are decidedly meaty in nature, going from the ubiquitous beef carpaccio, to a foie gras terrine, and OH! What's that? Steak tartare? Droooool. I then proceed to interview our Danish server on the tartare, asking him if it's knife cut or made using a grinder (grinder, boo!!!!); what's in the seasoning (chili, pepper, etc....). It sounded promising, and I ordered it. Put simply, it wasn't great. So much so, that I didn't finish it. The meat might have been good, but it was really kind of mushy (grinder 'oblige'), the seasoning was bland, and it was served with crisps... hmmm.For steaks we ordered the Uruguayan fillet, the American rib eye, and the danish bone-in rib eye. All steaks were cooked to perfection (medium rare), and sliced for us to share, table side. Personally, I don't care much for the 20 month dry-aged version of the Danish steaks... yes, they have more flavor, but the lack of natural marbling makes me lean towards to American, corn fed versions that have a bit more render.My problem with MASH wasn't the booze, nor was it its flagship steaks. My problem with MASH is with regards to its sides, which were pretty disappointing. The bone marrow was spongy, not nicely seasoned, and very rubbery in texture. I know what you're thinking... it's bone marrow, what did you expect, Shy? But there's rubbery, and then there's silky smooth...The fries were mushy, and were left untouched. The cream spinach was smothered in cheese, which really wasn't necessary. The spicy chopped jalapenos weren't hot in the least.The bill came down to about 80£ per person (with wine and cocktails). Yes, it's pricey. But so are all the high end steak houses in London (and around the world... ). But for 80£ I'll get a better food experience at Hawksmoor or a fuller American experience at Balthazar. But, as a less crowded alternative to the American Bar, or the craptastic Bob Bob Ricard, the 1 hr queue at Pitt Cue Co. for cocktails in Soho, MASH is great. Will definitely come back for drinks, and just steak with green salad (probably a healthier course of action). Or just keep eating steak at Hawksmoor.

E6UIyDIh9M1boW0nahK9Xg.text: Came here looking for decent cocktail during my brief but phrenetic overnight in London.  Place was nearly empty.  I thought Mash was a play on "bangers and mash" but discovered it was short for Modern American Steak House.  While my two bartender mates (I'll call them Jacque and Jack) were boasting of the american fare, I had to question the strategy due to lack of patrons.  But, back to the cocktail.  I ordered a negroni style drink, and was "assaulted" by my two mixologists who were playfully arguing who could make the better cocktail.  90 minutes and several small pro bono snifters of Sazaurac, Ryes, Steeped Whiskies, Bourbons, Bitters later.  I think they are neck and neck for first place!  Thanks Jacque and Jack for the lively conversation and livelier libations!  If you are taking in a play near Piccadilly Circus, stop in and grab one of their potent potables.

fmhHC6QjBfp1eYc4RViO3Q.text: Like any cocktail bar I recommend sitting at the bar counter and visiting at off peak hours (Tues night say). This allows you the chance to engage the staff and watch the theatrics of the cocktail making with more ease. For me this was having a drink made not from the menu but at the bar man's choice. Beast of the Buffalo it was called, and it was perfect.

photos.caption: Photo of MASH - London, United Kingdom. The Beast of the Buffalo. Bar mans choice.

Y4cMHg496C2gQDNCyP-PVg.text: We booked for the pre/post theatre menu as we were seeing a show last night and arrived a little early so we were shown to the bar to wait for our table. It is an absolutely stunning restaurant and we couldn't believe all this was under the streets of Soho. At the bar I had a MASH Pilsner (fresh and clean as you'd expect) and my wife had the Cidre Breton which she very much enjoyed.We were shown to our table and had a very attentive waiter who provided us with menus and water. We ordered, American steak with mashed potato (sirloin) for my wife and the Uruguayan rib-eye with mac and cheese for myself. We also ordered 2 lemon meringue pies. This is where the disappointment started to set in. From the point we ordered to the point food arrived on our table it was about 40 minutes. It was not busy in the restaurant and it was the beginning of evening service so I would NEVER expect to have to wait 40 minutes for 2 steaks in these circumstances. To top it off, the couple on the table next to us arrived after us, ordered after us and received their food before us. (Not to mention the fact that they kept asking the waiting staff to take pictures of them and their food with us awkwardly trying to enjoy our evening in the background)The food, when it arrived, was very nice indeed. My wifes' steak was cooked to a perfect well done and mine, although a little rarer than I would normally have, was delicious. The sides and sauces were also very good. After the delightful main, we were excited for the lemon meringue pie which is one of our favourites. What arrived was not lemon meringue pie. Sure, it was a pie and there was some curd in it with the tiniest bit of meringue covering it, but it could barely be called lemon meringue pie. The pastry and the ice cream on the side were the best bits. The curd hardly tasted of lemons at all and the meringue was millimetres thick.This was a disappointing end to the meal which otherwise would've been fine.I would definitely return and try something off the a la carte menu and also take up the recommendation of a friend and try the bone marrow side.I'm sure the timing of the service was an aberration and that if I returned it would be better. I look forward to that return visit.

d9I72BEpjAVnGbTtd3OgXA.text: Steak was quite ok and well cooked, of course, but not worth the price. Just the beef is above GBP 30. I defenitely had better and bolder steak dishes in other large european citys.So if it has to be a sophisticated steak in London, I know where it's rather good. (man). ;-)

Kp9uwvCwkRx_nqaNZTqGjw.text: Excellent place and service, attention was very good, the dishes served excellently and exact portions, the flavor was wonderful, little pricey

f-3IrLPEGx4A7a87Q6cpyQ.text: In short: Go there. Get some Danish prime beef. I had a sirloin steak and it was one of the best steaks ever. They also have wonderful wines. And do delicious desserts.Last Saturday I went down to take a look at this new London meat temple, MASH - Modern American Steak House. As I didn't know how busy the evening might be, I went there quite early. Nice smiling staff were greeting me when I entered the premises. Now comes a little surprise, as the restaurant is deep down below the surface. So I walked down the enormous and nicely styled stairs before I arrived at the second reception. Even more beautifully smiling staff were waiting to serve me. Quickly I was shown my table and got the menu to learn about their treats. First, the dining hall is huge. With a high ceiling and warm colours. It was not too busy, but I reckon even when it is busy, it is not as loud as some other well-known London steak restaurants. I have to admit, that I felt a bit awkward when I arrived and there were so many staff standing around and waiting for me (or any other guest coming down the stairs). But again, I was coming early, and they just opened a few weeks ago, probably they just play safe to be sure they really do well in the first weeks.So I looked at the wine list. It's a long and impressive list. Even if you're not planning to buy a bottle, you find a decent selection there. I only couldn't find the wines by the glass at first. Simply because they're not on the wine list, but on the regular menu. That solved, I could look for some pleasing drink. I was interested in two whites, one was the recommendation by the waiter - or sommelier - and the second was some US Riesling called "Kung Fu Girl". After I couldn't decide, I was offered to simply taste both and then decide. Great service! I sampled the Kung Fu Girl with it's cool name and the stylish label. It tasted interesting, but I liked the recommendation, Seresin, Sauvignon Blanc, NZ, much better. So I ended up with a few sips of the tantalising Kung Fu Girl, and then could indulge in this beautiful Seresin. Not surprisingly, the wine went down well with the tasty bread and butter. Again, very friendly and attentive service.Once the wine was sorted, the next challenge came up. Choosing the main. I knew, that I wanted some steak, but unfortunately that decision fell short of narrowing down the menu by much. Before I went there, I read that they are a Danish company, so I selected one of their Danish options - a sirloin steak. Usually I mostly go for fillet, but I just could not resist trying the "up to 70 days" aged Danish prime beef. I might be biased, as I have sort of a weak spot for most things Scandinavian, but this sirloin really beats most fillet steaks in tenderness and taste. Easily. It was very delicious and moist, with a great crust. I'm not a big fan of their bernaise sauce. The pepper sauce was nice, although it was no peppercorn sauce. The chips were good as well and crispy, but nothing spectacular. But the sirloin was just great. Best without sauce, then you taste much more of this great meat. For dessert, I ordered the cheesecake with raspberry sorbet, and liked it almost as much as the steak. The coffee, well, it is okay, not too bad, but unfortunately not as good as the other offerings. Like at most other restaurants.In my opinion, MASH London is one of the best - if not the best - steak houses around. If they keep the service up like this, even when busy and once the first few months behind, they will definitely be a strong contender in the London meat competition. I'm already looking forward to going back to have another steak!

TDiNWrsxuke4El85VyWqYg.text: Expensive? Yes, but if you wasn't aware of that before entering the restaurant, youll realise it the moment you walk in. Extravagant design in general, and the steaks are amazing. I'm not giving it 5 starts due to the prices, but with that being said I still enjoyed every second of the experience.

T6azaXH3gDqf63CDby01lA.text: Expensive but you will have a great time. Steaks are amazing and in a broad price range. Wine menu fantadtic but quite pricey!! Sides are good and can be shared. American, "mad men" style of dining. Only problem is the total absence of proper whiskey / scotches on the bar menu!

82aso--NGcVGeXw92O0WYA.text: Lovely decor and huge interior- the seating is comfy and the drinks are nice, staff are also very friendly - it is a slick establishment and appears to appeal to a slick clientele but I was still made to feel welcome in my backpack and trainers.

photos.caption: Photo of MASH - London, United Kingdom

G6anDvu8BBbvyKHnLnkrIw.text: Amazing service, [Amand is the best] incredible food. Absolutely worth a stop: even the bread is to die for! Attention to detail is insane: sawed, branded ice cubes

SZQqzzC3rc9Y4sJdSUvWiA.text: At a steakhouse you expect a thick charred steak with decadent sides. Unfortunately, Mash did not live up to this standard, charging top sterling for a very thin underwhelming steak. It was evident that the grill top was not hot enough as the char marks were almost non-existent. The sides were nothing to write home about, as an example the Mac and Cheese, which has now become a steakhouse staple, showed up dry and tasteless. The harsh criticism comes from over the top prices with underwhelming steaks. Service was on par and the ambiance is quite nice but I would not recommend this as a top steakhouse in London.

w6E2E7q9GfR-aKDtzKkgVg.text: Came here for new years eve and was not disappointed. First off, it is pricey BUT you pay for the quality, ambiance, and service. It is a top class dining experience.From the outside you don't realize how big the place is. It has a beautiful layout.We ordered some red wine and it was on point. The steaks were also awesome! They have options from all over the world. For sides we ordered the mac and cheese, tomato salad, and these other fried balls. I normally dont like mac and cheese but this was amazing. The caesar salad was the best i have had. Order it!!!Awesome experience! Highly recommended!

photos.caption: Photo of MASH - London, United Kingdom
Photo of MASH - London, United Kingdom
Photo of MASH - London, United Kingdom. Filet

IgHRjFkx3DnGUnP8nrrL0A.text: MASH: a proper American steak house in London!Its my second time at Mash and I have to admit its a pretty solid place. The cocktail bar is great and the overall atmosphere makes this place good for friends hang out as much as a romantic evening.My friend and I came this time to take advantages of the 50% off Wagyu beef and it was soooo worth it.Service was impeccable, cocktails are really good. I would give a miss to the desserts as they are pretty standard.

photos.caption: Photo of MASH - London, United Kingdom
Photo of MASH - London, United Kingdom
Photo of MASH - London, United Kingdom

ImUQAiwzixKhBgMAaAh8aQ.text: MASH is always my lifesaver when I make my annual work trip over the pond. Unfortunately, British food isn't my forté, and I find the cuisine to be bland and unappetizing. MASH feels like coming home. The beautiful and spacious restaurant is polished, classy, yet still comfortable. All the food I have tried, from appetizers to side dishes, to the mouthwatering steaks, have been impeccable. The wine list is vast and impressive, and all the waiters are on point with their recommendations and knowledge of the menu offerings. On top of that, they are so friendly, and even remember my boss when he returns every year. This is definitely the evening I look forward to the most every time I travel to London! See you in 2018, MASH!

vzGXEqexnyo3siwKI0Z3lA.text: Good ambiance. The main entrance opens to a cloakroom then you have to go two floors down for the bar/restaurant.The decor is very nice, with a huge bar, meat on display, wine cabinets and staff are quite attentive as there were not too many patrons about on a Sunday evening. The lights are quite dim at night but you can still see the menu at least.We went there for the 50% off Japanese waygu steak deal and unfortunately this was sold out. We were offered the Australian waygu steak at 50% off instead and 4 of us diners ordered 800g of medium rare steak. The steak was really nicely cooked and melts in your mouth. I didn't like the fact that there were a bit of fat on some of my pieces of steak but this is personal preference. It was very nice that the waiter would offer to cut up your steaks for you (looks like flat iron steak at the end!).Sides were very good as well. Chilli fries was a huge portion. The cheesy spinach was also a hit for cheese lovers. I didn't like the bone marrow myself but then this is not a side I would normally order.Meal was pleasant, and it was perfect for a special occasion.Food and drink (1 bottle house wine, still water + 1 cocktail) came to approx £40 per person with the 50% off wagyu steak offer.

photos.caption: Photo of MASH - London, United Kingdom
Photo of MASH - London, United Kingdom
Photo of MASH - London, United Kingdom

gkJUbxxqGDGv6i3bSrJRlw.text: Awesome steak place, the venue and the service are superb. Quality of the meat and food was great. Went for the Danish ribeye, rare, however it wasn't in the right cooking, a little bit more medium rare.  The waitress mentioned it was due to the kind of meat I ordered, but i would have appreciated the comment when ordering, not after. Being there for whiskey and cocktail too. Great selection of drinks, specially rums, whiskeys, bourbons and ryes.

photos.caption: Photo of MASH - London, United Kingdom

OJBFKmkcocnJZbBbpDyPyA.text: West End steakhouse, centrally located near Piccadilly underground, serving deliciously cooked steaks from the usual sources and also from Denmark, which I would recommend trying. Oddly though mash isn't available on the menu although you can 'special' order it!Didn't get as far as deserts so can't comment. There is a reasonably priced selection of wines on offer but don't expect much change from £100 pp although that did include 2 pre lunch cocktails. On that note the service at the bar was very disappointing for such a stylish restaurant. Make sure you are fit enough to negotiate the long staircase to the basement rest from street level.

SllfwkQgWkmn549-_smjVQ.text: We popped into MASH for late night cocktails after dinner and a wander round Lumiere festival.Tucked away two floors below street level, and on a quietish Sunday night, MASH had quite a secretive & illicit vibe.The venue itself is majestic, with two flights of red carpeted stairs leading down to a bar and dining room. With dim atmospheric lighting and retro American style decor, it definitely had a stylish vibe and very much impressed. We sat in the bar area, and were presented with a cocktail menu consisting of a book of postcards, one for each cocktails. The friendly barman brought us a small bowl of tasty popcorn to nibble on while making our choice, and even bought out another bowl when we'd got through the first one!After much musing on fancy-sounding ingredients, I went for the Spanish Harlem Cocktail - featuring a sunny lineup of gin, saffron, orange marmalade, vanilla, elderflower and lemon. It was fantastically fruity without being overly sweet, and the cranberry wrap for the straw was a wonderful touch. My companion went for the West Side Apertivo, which definitely tasted like tequila but still very drinkable, its intriguing combination of ingredients (tequila, Kamm & Sons, rhubarb, apple, lemon, almond, pink peppercorn syrup) offering up an unusal but satisfying taste.I'd definitely like to go to MASH for steak at a later date, as the cocktails were very enjoyable and I loved the feel of the place.

photos.caption: Photo of MASH - London, United Kingdom
Photo of MASH - London, United Kingdom

Ku-QJ9i281dtJA5StvfdVw.text: Such a nice job with a variety of dishes. And such a creative menu of steaks. The four of us loved this place. And Bianca was so helpful, attentive and pleasant.

x-geLaQnoDiEfGBchmRZnw.text: The interior of MASH is like a modern cathedral - once you get down to it though as it's two floors down from the initial reception. But once you get down there it's amazing - the bar is sensational and the actual dining room is vast and really just the finest looking steakhouse I've ever seen.We each had a steak, I enjoyed mine but my wife had a dry aged one and we both found it too game-y. But that's personal preference, as we know it was good steak, just not to our tastes. The one thing I adore here is the bearnaise sauce which is like flavoured butter that you can dip your steak into. Heck, you'd be able to dip pretty much anything into it and it'd be great.

t0GadSkwdEDohfP63oesNA.text: Pleasantly surprised as I had heard mixed things about MASH but found it an excellent steakhouse.  I had the Danish bone-in ribeye.  Most importantly, it was cooked exactly as ordered, medium rare, and if anything they erred on the rare side which is always a plus.  The steak had a very distinct aged, grassy flavor that I enjoyed.  Also had the tomatoes with feta, which was nice.  A good variety of tomatoes, despite it being out of season.Unfortunately, did not try anything else as was only there for lunch but my colleagues also commented that their steak was cooked perfectly.What is interesting about MASH is they give you a choice of at least six types of beef, ranging from British to Kobe to Australia to Denmark to the US.  I went Denmark, as mentioned earlier, but would have been nice to have some type of sampler.As others mentioned, it's expensive but all good steakhouses are.

mJt_wHw__x6fk1pLb4UfmQ.text: Steak restaurants are one of my favourite types of restaurant in general, and I finally got to give MASH a try last week!It's certainly the most impressive Steak restaurant I have eaten at...it's huge! Really nicely laid out, and plenty of staff to cover it's vast area! You burn your steak off with the long walk to the toilet and back!In terms of the food, I was expecting big things! And it was awesome, however it wasn't as good as Goodman's (number 1 for me) or Gaucho.The Steak itself was lovely, I had the 400g American Ribeye Meidum Rare which was lovely. However I tried a couple of other cuts that people on the table has and wasn't as impressed. I actually could not eat the bone in RIbeye as it was very chewy. However the reason this isn't a 5* is the starters. We tried all of them (literally). Then only one I was really impressed by was the Steak tartare. The scallops were nice, but just average. Likewise with he Beef carpaccio-good but nothing special.This place is 100% a must do, just to admire the building itself more than anything, and the food is really good. But I think for places in the same price range, food wise you can do a bit better!

photos.caption: Photo of MASH - London, United Kingdom. Mash Restaurant London
Photo of MASH - London, United Kingdom. American Ribeye Medium Rare

QNUzX6qaE88NXUwryc7LNQ.text: We'd been to MASH when it was newly opened for a Comic Relief benefit evening a couple of years ago, so we knew what to expect on our visit for my husband's birthday.While we enjoyed it the first time, it's just a bit expensive really. However, they were offering 50% off steaks in August Sunday-Thursday so we were excited to come back.The restaurant is in the basement and has loads of stairs (but there is a lift, of course). I really love the look of it - very retro American steak house. We were seated quickly by a nice waitress.We don't drink alcohol so just ordered Coke - which was mostly ice and a huge hunk of lemon.None of the starters appealed to us so we went right to mains. I had the Danish rib-eye and my husband had NY strip steak. We also had mashed potato and a caesar salad to share for our sides. Some yummy bread was brought to us while we waited.When I had ordered my steak, I asked for it medium. The waitress tried to convince me that I should get it medium rare they won't cook their dry aged beef more than medium. I persevered and said I wanted medium, but when it arrived, it was definitely medium rare - and the centre was only rare. I just ate what was a bit more cooked and left the rest, as we weren't checked on promptly enough to have the steak cooked more, and I'm also very loathe to send a steak back for more cooking as it usually gets really tough after cooking, resting, and re-cooking. Husband's NY strip was cooked as he requested.We both preferred the NY strip. My Danish ribeye had a very strong flavour and a dense texture. However, the NY strip didn't have a whole lot of flavour, really, and we should have gotten a sauce to go with it. Something in between the two would have been ideal.Our mashed potato and caesar salad were both tasty, but the mash especially was a small portion. It wasn't enough for one person, and definitely not enough for sharing. But at £5 for some mash, we just each had our spoonful and didn't worry about it. Since I left most of my steak and we didn't have much in the side department, we decided to have dessert, but when the menu came, we just couldn't bring ourselves to spend £10 on a panna cotta or some profiteroles.Our bill came and was around £65; which seemed high, until I realised that £13 of it was the optional service charge. 12.5% charged on the bill before the discount - insanity. We were there for 45 minutes. I had it removed and left a cash tip commiserate to the service we received. The waitress nearly knocked me over when we were leaving to get to the table to see how much cash we had left. I'd go back with an offer like we had, but unless you have an expense account, the premium they charge here for the location isn't quite appropriate for the food.

g4ij3zuVrxkUMoBRgZcZ0Q.text: We're spoilt for choice for great steak restaurants in London but I love MASH (Modern American Steak House).I've been loads of times and the food and service has always been impeccable. The place is huge. The cloakroom is at street level when you walk in. Then you can either take the lift (yes there's a lift) or two flights of stairs into the bowels of the place. Inside the restaurant, what immediately hits you is the scale of the whole place. It's like you've walked into a scene in Titanic - a huge ballroom of 20s glitz.The impressive bar (and equally impressive bar staff) greet you immediately. It's definitely worth getting there in enough time to enjoy a cocktail. For any whiskey lovers, the selection of American Rye is among the best in London - as is the Sazerac here. Go past the bar and the huge chillers of hanging meat and the place opens up into three sections of tables and booths. There are also two private dining rooms. I've no idea how many covers this place does at capacity but it's a lot.As I've said, the food and service are impeccable. I always go for the 600g American bone-in ribeye, mac and cheese, creamed spinach and fries. It's a lot but it's all I have and is consistently cooked well.As well as U.S. beef, you can choose cuts from Uruguay, Australia, Japanese Wagyu, Danish dry-aged (the cuts hanging in the chillers) and a British ribeye.The wine list is also immense - again one of the largest selections of US wines available in London.As mentioned, we are spoilt for choice in London but MASH is up there with the best. It's great for large groups, small groups or intimate dining. I've even used the bar as a starting point for a boozy night out.

photos.caption: Photo of MASH - London, United Kingdom. Steaks and sides!
Photo of MASH - London, United Kingdom. American 600g bone-in ribeye

BMOqtSsptKcdQTh4x8Nenw.text: Dined here last week.MASH is an acronym for Modern American Steak House, which it is. A huge subterranean space that served up some delicious Pan Fried Scallops, Porterhouse for two, Mac & Cheese, Mixed Tomato Salad, Profiteroles with Chocolate Sauce and Vanilla Ice Cream, and decaf cappuccino.Good stuff.

photos.caption: Photo of MASH - London, United Kingdom. Profiteroles with Chocolate Sauce and Vanilla Ice Cream
Photo of MASH - London, United Kingdom. Mixed Tomato Salad
Photo of MASH - London, United Kingdom. Porterhouse for two.

S1znjfy-xqlbd53c04b51w.text: Had dinner here last night with family for the second time. We like MASH because of the decor and atmosphere. We headed to the bar for drinks as we were early. Started with the Malbec. The waiter was friendly and had a good sense of humour. Then headed to our table. Service was good and prompt. The waitress was helpful in giving advice on the best cut for us based on what we like. The dinner wine list is quite extensive but we decided to stick with the Malbec. I started with the tartare, my partner had the scallops and son had the tuna tartare. I had the American fillet which was medium rare and tender. Sides of chilli chips and spinach. Others had New York rib eye - well done and medium rare. They enjoyed it. Dessert was the key lime pie, strawberry sorbet and ice cream.

photos.caption: Photo of MASH - London, United Kingdom. Scallops
Photo of MASH - London, United Kingdom. MASH tartare
Photo of MASH - London, United Kingdom. New York fillet

10evk2aoRX_TydZqUi78WQ.text: One of my favorite dining experiences. Yes, it is VERY pricey but the staff is so attentive and helpful with the wine and food menu. The wagyu melts in your mouth. The wine they picked out was amazing. It's not your average dinner, it's an experience you'll remember forever!

hNb-2UP2cnbE8IMBlWRhrw.text: A Danish steakhouse....Deceivingly large - like entering Marry Poppins hand bag.  As you walk down the stairs a massive dining room awaits.Service was ok.  Food was reasonable.  Nothing particular to complain about, however the food isn't on par with Hawksmoor or Goodmans.I went for a Scottish ribeye.  Very tasty.  Wouldn't recommend, but wouldn't avoid either.

ptotZqrJJ1DbYTD8J1Xb1A.text: Was disappointed by quality of the steak. Thin and little flavor except for the salt. 1/3 was fat and have had much better steaks in other restaurants in London. Onion rings were very greasy and I could not eat.
